"Japan's Nikkei 225 fell 6.7% early Monday, extending losses from last week due to concerns over the U.S. economy dealing with high interest rates. The index later recovered some ground. The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq also experienced declines, amplifying fears of a potential recession in the U.S.Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index plunged 6.7% early Monday before recovering some lost ground, extending sell-offs that began last week.\n\nThe Nikkei had shed more than 2,400 points to 33,488.0"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Tokyo"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Japan"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Investing", "label": "dmoz/Business/Investing", "wgt": 60}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Stocks_and_Bonds", "label": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Stocks and Bonds", "wgt": 67}, {"uri": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Day_Trading", "label": "dmoz/Business/Investing/Day Trading", "wgt": 62}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 98}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 91}, "sentiment": -0.2, "breakingScore": 0.3351081301180465}
{"uri": "2024-08-442256039", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "19:05:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T19:05:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T18:07:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9450980424880981, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/ap/business/stock-market-today-dow-drops-800-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_91d7786b-2233-51f7-9b0e-dfdeb8ab800c.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 800 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "Stocks are tumbling Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks are tumbling Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.2% in afternoon trading, potentially on pace for its worst day since 2022, and on track for its first back-to-back loss of more than 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 807 points, or 2%, as of 1:10 p.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was 2.6% lower as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a better than three-in-four chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 9.7% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 27.7%, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 2.9%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are too difficult to meet.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite down by more than 10% from its record set in the middle of last month.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates had been rebounding at the same time tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.5%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.81% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nAmid all the fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advising caution.\n\n\"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" according to Lara Castleton, U.S. head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe points out the U.S. economy is still growing, and inflation is still slowing. The S&P 500, meanwhile, isn't far off its record set two weeks ago. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices surged after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy will burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled 3.8% Friday to bring its loss for the week to 4.8%.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 954 points, or 2.4%, as of 11:30 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was 2.9% lower as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a better than three-in-four chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 9.9% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.5%, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 2%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are too difficult to meet.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite down by more than 10% from its record set in the middle of last month.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates had been rebounding at the same time tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 4.2%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.81% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nAmid all the fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advising caution.\n\n\"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" according to Lara Castleton, U.S. head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe points out the U.S. economy is still growing, and inflation is still slowing. The S&P 500, meanwhile, isn't far off its record set two weeks ago. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices surged after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy will burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled 3.7% Friday to bring its loss for the week to 4.8%.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Wall Street"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interest_rate", "type": "wiki", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9785897", "eventUri": "eng-9785897", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2941176470588235, "wgt": 240, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-442038647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "14:55:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T14:55:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T14:36:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9411764740943909, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/stock-market-today-weak-us-jobs-data-pummels-markets-as-a-global-sell-off-whips/article_01ad410a-bc29-5ed6-a36f-26d1616bab4e.html", "title": "Stock market today: Weak US jobs data pummels markets as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "U.S. stocks are tumbling on worries about whether the U.S. economy's growth can hold up until the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, as a sell-off for stocks whips all the way around the world back to Wall Street\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- U.S. stocks are tumbling Friday on worries about whether the U.S. economy's growth can hold up until the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, as a sell-off for stocks whips all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.4% in morning trading, potentially on track for its worst day since 2022, and on pace for its first back-to-back loss of more than 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 608 points, or 1.5%, as of 10:15 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was 3.4% lower.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas most hurt by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long in its zeal to stifle inflation. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and support the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a nearly two-in-three chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said on Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 12.1% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 29.3%, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 1.4%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains are growing too difficult to meet.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates were rebounding at the same time, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too on Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.9%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.81% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nThe yield on the two-year Treasury, which more closely follows expectations for Fed action, fell to 3.89% from 4.15% late Thursday and is back to where it was in May 2023.\n\nAmid all the fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advising caution.\n\n\"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" according to Lara Castleton, U.S. head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe points out the U.S. economy is still growing, and inflation is still coming down. The S&P 500, meanwhile, isn't far off its record set two weeks ago. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks extended losses this week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus.\n\nStock indexes also fell across much of Europe.\n\nThe nerve-wracking week for markets has come even as central banks in Japan, the United States and England acted pretty much as expected. Japan raised its benchmark rate, the Fed stood pat and the Bank of England lowered its key rate for the first time in more than four years.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride, with oil prices surging after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears conflict in the Middle East might escalate into a wider war. But prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries about the economy. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled 3.5% Friday to $73.62 and brought its loss for the week to 4.6%.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.\n\nMore from this section\n\nACES Quality Management Enhances ACES Deposit Account Audit Pack for Banks and Credit Unions\n\nChurch of Scientology Forum on the Need for Sustainability\n\nChampioning Environmental {"uri": "2024-08-442370155", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "22:13:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T22:13:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T20:41:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/stock-market-today-dow-drops-600-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_4e607e9d-b928-5177-bbe1-f1ba14817ce2.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 600 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 1.8% for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a 70% probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 8.8% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.1%, for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and forecast a loss for the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple held steadier, up 0.7%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" were the main reasons the S&P 500 set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10% below its record set last month. That level of drop is what traders call a \"correction.\"\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates began rebounding sharply last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.5%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nAll told, the S&P 500 fell 100.12 points to 5,346.56. The Dow dropped 610.71 to 39.737.26, and the Nasdaq composite fell 417.98 to 16,776.16.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders forecasted deeper cuts to rates coming from the Federal Reserve. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and deflate a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices leaped after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy would burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude dropped back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-442307853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "20:22:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T20:22:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T19:18:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/stock-market-today-dow-drops-775-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_ec213959-cbf5-52ef-b2aa-14e15f5ee902.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 775 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks are tumbling Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.1% in afternoon trading and on track for its worst back-to-back loss since December. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 775 points, or 1.9%, with a little more than an hour remaining in trading, and the Nasdaq composite was 2.6% lower as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a nearly three-in-four chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 9.2% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.7% and on pace for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 2.2%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are too difficult to meet.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite down by more than 10% from its record set in the middle of last month.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates had been rebounding last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.6%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices surged after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy will burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-442043273", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "14:59:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T14:59:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T14:36:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9333333373069763, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/stock-market-today-weak-us-jobs-data-pummels-markets-as-a-global-sell-off-whips/article_ec213959-cbf5-52ef-b2aa-14e15f5ee902.html", "title": "Stock market today: Weak US jobs data pummels markets as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- U.S. stocks are tumbling Friday on worries about whether the U.S. economy's growth can hold up until the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, as a sell-off for stocks whips all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.4% in morning trading, potentially on track for its worst day since 2022, and on pace for its first back-to-back loss of more than 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 608 points, or 1.5%, as of 10:15 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was 3.4% lower.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas most hurt by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long in its zeal to stifle inflation. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and support the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a nearly two-in-three chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said on Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 12.1% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 29.3%, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 1.4%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains are growing too difficult to meet.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates were rebounding at the same time, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too on Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.9%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.81% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nThe yield on the two-year Treasury, which more closely follows expectations for Fed action, fell to 3.89% from 4.15% late Thursday and is back to where it was in May 2023.\n\nAmid all the fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advising caution.\n\n\"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" according to Lara Castleton, U.S. head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe points out the U.S. economy is still growing, and inflation is still coming down. The S&P 500, meanwhile, isn't far off its record set two weeks ago. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks extended losses this week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus.\n\nStock indexes also fell across much of Europe.\n\nThe nerve-wracking week for markets has come even as central banks in Japan, the United States and England acted pretty much as expected. Japan raised its benchmark rate, the Fed stood pat and the Bank of England lowered its key rate for the first time in more than four years.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride, with oil prices surging after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears conflict in the Middle East might escalate into a wider war. But prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries about the economy. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled 3.5% Friday to $73.62 and brought its loss for the week to 4.6%.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recession", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Recession"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dividend", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9785897", "eventUri": "eng-9785897", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.2784313725490196, "wgt": 238, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-08-442338288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "21:14:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T21:14:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T20:41:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/stock-market-today-dow-drops-600-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_01ad410a-bc29-5ed6-a36f-26d1616bab4e.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 600 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 1.8% for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a 70% probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 8.8% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.1%, for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and forecast a loss for the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple held steadier, up 0.7%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" were the main reasons the S&P 500 set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10% below its record set last month. That level of drop is what traders call a \"correction.\"\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates began rebounding sharply last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.5%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nAll told, the S&P 500 fell 100.12 points to 5,346.56. The Dow dropped 610.71 to 39.737.26, and the Nasdaq composite fell 417.98 to 16,776.16.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders forecasted deeper cuts to rates coming from the Federal Reserve. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and deflate a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices leaped after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy would burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude dropped back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.\n\nMore from this section\n\nTodd Henne, Expert in Helping Businesses Meet Financial Goals, Joins TAG CXO\n\nLenderLogix Integrates Income, Employment Verification Services from Truv into LiteSpeed Mortgage Point-of-Sale\n\nHarris has secured enough Democratic delegate votes to become their party's nominee, chair says", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, {"uri": "2024-08-442616870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "07:24:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T07:24:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T06:51:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/aug/03/high-rate-jitters-take-markets-low/", "title": "High-rate jitters take markets low", "body": "Major indexes slip after hiring slowdown rattles investors\n\nNEW YORK -- Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 1.8% for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a 70% probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 8.8% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.1%, for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and forecast a loss for the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple held steadier, up 0.7%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" were the main reasons the S&P 500 set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10% below its record set last month. That level of drop is what traders call a \"correction.\"\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates began rebounding sharply last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they also tumbled Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.5%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nAll told, the S&P 500 fell 100.12 points to 5,346.56. The Dow dropped 610.71 to 39.737.26, and the Nasdaq composite fell 417.98 to 16,776.16.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders forecasted deeper cuts to rates coming from the Federal Reserve. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell from 3.98% late Thursday to 3.79%, continuing its drop from April's 4.70%.\n\nCommodity prices also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices leaped after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy would burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude dropped back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach of The Associated {"uri": "2024-08-442312928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "20:32:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T20:32:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T20:09:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/nation/stock-market-today-dow-drops-600-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_e332c1ee-67b3-5eb4-b75d-989c19a99d30.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 600 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation. The S&P 500 fell 1.8% Friday for its first back-to-back loss of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4%. A report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than expected sent fear through markets. Intel sank to its worst day in 50 years after reporting weaker-than-expected profits and suspending its dividend. Treasury yields tumbled as expectations built for how deeply the Federal Reserve will cut rates in September.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks are tumbling Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.1% in afternoon trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 775 points, or 1.9%, with a little more than an hour remaining in trading, and the Nasdaq composite was 2.6% lower as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a nearly three-in-four chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 9.2% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.7% and on pace for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 2.2%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are too difficult to meet.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite down by more than 10% from its record set in the middle of last month.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates had been rebounding last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.6%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices surged after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy will burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8256185029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "15:16:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T15:16:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T15:15:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9176470637321472, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/news/nation-world/stock-market-today-weak-us-jobs-data-pummels-markets-as-a-global-sell-off-whips/article_fb7f32c1-f18f-59da-b1a7-f5aec61db0a1.html", "title": "Stock market today: Weak US jobs data pummels markets as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- U.S. stocks are tumbling Friday on worries about whether the U.S. economy can hold up amid the countdown for a cut to interest rates by the Federal Reserve, as a sell-off for stocks whips all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.5% in late morning trading, potentially on pace for its worst day since 2022, and on track for its first back-to-back loss of more than 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 806 points, or 2%, as of 10:45 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was 3.1% lower.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long in its zeal to stifle inflation. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and support the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a roughly two-in-three chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said on Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 11.9% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 27.9%, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 2.4%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains are growing too difficult to meet.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite down by more than 10% from its record set in the middle of last month.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates had been rebounding at the same time tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 4.2%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.82% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nAmid all the fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advising caution.\n\n\"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" according to Lara Castleton, U.S. head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe points out the U.S. economy is still growing, and inflation is still coming down. The S&P 500, meanwhile, isn't far off its record set two weeks ago. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks extended losses this week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, and stock indexes fell across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ridet this week. Oil prices surged after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy will burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled 3.4% Friday to $73.73 and brought its loss for the week to 4.5%.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-442092460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "15:50:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T15:50:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T15:47:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/stock-market-today-dow-drops-900-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_01ad410a-bc29-5ed6-a36f-26d1616bab4e.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 900 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "Stocks are tumbling Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Stocks are tumbling Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 was sinking by 2.5% in midday trading, potentially on pace for its worst day since 2022, and on track for its first back-to-back loss of more than 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 954 points, or 2.4%, as of 11:30 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was 2.9% lower as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a better than three-in-four chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 9.9% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.5%, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and said it expects to lose money in the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple was holding steadier, up 2%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" have been the main reasons the S&P 500 has set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are too difficult to meet.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite down by more than 10% from its record set in the middle of last month.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates had been rebounding at the same time tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 4.2%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders raised their expectations for how deeply the Federal Reserve would have to cut interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.81% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nAmid all the fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advising caution.\n\n\"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" according to Lara Castleton, U.S. head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe points out the U.S. economy is still growing, and inflation is still slowing. The S&P 500, meanwhile, isn't far off its record set two weeks ago. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed the value of the Japanese yen higher against the U.S. dollar, potentially hurting profits for exporters and deflating a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell week as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices have also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices surged after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah that fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy will burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude tumbled 3.7% Friday to bring its loss for the week to 4.8%.\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.\n\nMore from this section\n\nInformative Research's Penny Gonzalez Named 2024 HousingWire Insider\n\nLinguist Jeff Siegel Publishes Comprehensive Nama Dictionary\n\nKhalid Sheikh Mohammed, accused as the main plotter of 9/11 attacks, agrees
