{"uri": "8260430341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "16:28:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T16:28:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T16:19:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13711025/Dow-drops-860-points-Japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-1987-amid-U-S-economy-worries.html", "title": "Dow drops 860 points, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 2.4% in midday trading and on track for its worst day since 2022. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was reeling by 864 points, or 2.2%, as of 11:40 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 2.7%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a global sell-off that began last week. Japan\u00b4s Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday\u00b4s report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it\u00b4s all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nProfessional investors cautioned that some technical factors could be amplifying the action in markets, but the losses were still neck-snapping. South Korea\u00b4s Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped below $55,000 from more than $61,000 on Friday.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1%.\n\nSpecialist Dilip Patel works at his post on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.(AP Photo/Richard Drew)\n\nThat\u00b4s in part because traders began wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, briefly sank below 3.70% during the morning from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April. It later recovered and pulled back to 3.90%.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn\u00b4t really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nThe U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession within the next 12 months following Friday\u00b4s jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may also simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\n\"Markets tend to move higher like they\u00b4re climbing stairs, and they go down like they\u00b4re falling out a window,\" according to JJ Kinahan, CEO of IG North America. He chalks much of the recent worries to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself.\"\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero. Such a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nU.S. stocks pared their losses Monday after a report said growth for U.S. services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management. Treasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy\u00b4s strength took sharp losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 3.7%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled as the market\u00b4s most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech\u00b4s momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 3.2% Monday after Warren Buffett\u00b4s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that\u00b4s become the poster child of Wall Street\u00b4s AI bonanza, fell even more, 5%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia\u00b4s new AI chip is delayed. The recent selling has trimmed Nvidia's gain for the year to nearly 106% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies are the market\u00b4s biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That\u00b4s adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could impact markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could affect the election itself.\n\nThe threat of a recession is likely to put Vice President Kamala Harris on the defensive. But slower growth could also further reduce inflation and force former President Donald Trump to pivot from his current focus on higher prices to outlining ways to revive the economy.\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach, Matt Ott and Christopher Rugaber contributed.\n\nFILE - Trader John Romolo works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Aug. 2, 2024. (AP Photo/Ahn Young-joon)\n\nSpecialist Glenn Carell works at his post on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world. {"uri": "2024-08-444683449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T14:43:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/08/05/nearly-everything-on-wall-street-tumbles-over-worries-u-s-is-headed-for-recession/", "title": "Nearly everything on Wall Street tumbles over worries U.S. is headed for recession", "body": "Specialist Glenn Carell works at his post on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on Monday. Richard Drew/Associated Press\n\nNEW YORK -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 3.1% in morning trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 956 points, or 2.4%, as of 10:10 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 4%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped 9.5%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.4%.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.81% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\nU.S. stocks pared their losses a bit Monday morning after a report said growth for U.S. services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 4.4%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 9.1%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 97% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could impact markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could also affect the election itself.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nModify your screen name\n\nJoin the Conversation\n\nPlease sign into your Press Herald account to participate in conversations below. If you do not have an account, you can register or subscribe. Questions? {"uri": "2024-08-444650647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:17:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:17:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:57:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/dow-drops-nearly-1-000-and-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-on-u/article_66a43a6d-9cfc-5de1-b442-b6b232e024e6.html", "title": "Dow drops nearly 1,000, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 on U.S. economy fears", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 3.1% in early trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 996 points, or 2.5%, as of 9:50 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 3.8%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3% and bitcoin dropped 12%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.6%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.79% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% chance of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 4.6% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 8.3%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 98.7% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach and Matt Ott {"uri": "8260430335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "16:29:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T16:29:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T16:19:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13711071/Wall-Street-tumbles-fears-slowing-US-economy-worsen.html", "title": "Wall Street tumbles as fears about slowing US economy worsen", "body": "Nearly everything on Wall Street tumbled on Monday as fears about a slowing US economy worsen and set off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 2.4% in midday trading and on track for its worst day since 2022.\n\nThe Dow Jones Industrial Average was reeling by 864 points, or 2.2%, and the Nasdaq composite slid 2.7%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a global sell-off that began last week.\n\nJapan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nThe New York Stock Exchange (Peter Morgan/AP)\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing US employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected.\n\nThat was the latest piece of data on the US economy to come in weaker than expected, and it has all raised fears the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the US economy by too much for too long through high interest rates, in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nProfessional investors cautioned that some technical factors could be amplifying the action in markets, but the losses were still neck-snapping.\n\nSouth Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped below 55,000 dollars (\u00a343,000) from more than 61,000 dollars (\u00a347,800) on Friday.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1%.\n\nThat is in part because traders began wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on September 18.\n\nTraders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on Monday (Richard Drew/AP)\n\nThe yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, briefly sank below 3.70% during the morning from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April. It later recovered and pulled back to 3.90%.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management.\n\n\"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like Covid, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nThe US economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nThe Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022 - being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession within the next 12 months after Friday's jobs report.\n\nA monitor shows the Nikkei 225 stock index in Tokyo on Monday (Shohei Miyano/Kyodo News/AP)\n\nBut he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances\".\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may also simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates.\n\nCritics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\n\"Markets tend to move higher like they're climbing stairs, and they go down like they're falling out a window,\" said JJ Kinahan, chief executive of IG North America.\n\nHe credits much of the recent worry to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself\".\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero.\n\nSuch a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nUS stocks pared their losses on Monday after a report said growth for US services businesses was a touch stronger than expected.\n\nGrowth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management.\n\nTreasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took sharp losses on the fears about a slowdown.\n\nThe small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 3.7%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel.\n\nApple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet.\n\nA set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 3.2% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that has become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 5%.\n\nAnalysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. The recent selling has trimmed Nvidia's gain for the year to nearly 106% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies are the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil.\n\nThat is adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming US elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could affect markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could affect the election itself.\n\nThe threat of a recession is likely to put vice president Kamala Harris on the defensive.\n\nBut slower growth could also further reduce inflation and force former president Donald Trump to change from his current focus on higher prices to outlining ways to revive the economy.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail {"uri": "2024-08-442351061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "21:35:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T21:35:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T21:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/ap/business/stock-market-today-dow-drops-600-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off/article_a6c9970c-50dc-11ef-b129-07af03c0f970.html", "title": "Stock market today: Dow drops 600 on weak jobs data as a global sell-off whips back to Wall Street", "body": "NEW YORK -- Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 1.8% for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply. It followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nValparaiso University to eliminate 30 academic programs Mind on Money: For the economy, time will tell Pierogi Fest grew from one vendor who sold out in an hour to a wall-to-wall crush of starch-seeking revelers, expects record attendance UPDATE: Valpo woman identified as deceased in fatal U.S. 20 crash Portillo's set to open Orland Park drive-thru by 2025 Region native captures Olympic medal in Paris Police release photos of woman sought in check scam Davich: 'Mr. Safety' killed at dangerous bike trail intersection in Region 5-year-old dies after being found in pool, Griffith police say 24-Hour Pierogi People: Annual Whiting festival elevates the dumpling to an artform NWI Business Ins and Outs: Cajun Express, Fuerte Restaurant, Frankie's Philly Steak, The Waxi Taxi, Phenix Salon Suites and Boot Barn opening Pastor seeks to dump video of him allegedly battering child Former U.S. Steel South Works site to be transformed into quantum computing park Man found in Region basement beaten with ax handle, cops say State police arrest 19 during blitzes on I-94, I-65, department says\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a 70% probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 8.8% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.1%, for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend payment and forecast a loss for the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple held steadier, up 0.7%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" were the main reasons the S&P 500 set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10% below its record set last month. That level of drop is what traders call a \"correction.\"\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates began rebounding sharply last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled too Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.5%, more than the rest of the market.\n\nAll told, the S&P 500 fell 100.12 points to 5,346.56. The Dow dropped 610.71 to 39.737.26, and the Nasdaq composite fell 417.98 to 16,776.16.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders forecasted deeper cuts to rates coming from the Federal Reserve. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79% from 3.98% late Thursday and from 4.70% in April.\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8%. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and deflate a boom in tourism.\n\nChinese stocks fell as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices leaped after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy would burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude dropped back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nThe business news you {"uri": "8257367624", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "12:09:05", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T12:09:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T12:00:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://omaha.com/eedition/sunrise/articles/dow-drops-600-points-on-weak-jobs-data/article_0d474ff1-ff87-5a3b-95ec-5b62b9e2b07c.html", "title": "Dow drops 600 points on weak jobs data", "body": "NEW YORK -- Stocks tumbled Friday on worries that the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 100.12 points, or 1.8%, to 5,346.56 for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610.71 points, or 1.5%, to 39.737.26, and the Nasdaq composite fell 417.98 points, or 2.4%, to 16,776.16 as a sell-off for stocks whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing that hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than economists expected sent fear through markets. It followed weaker-than-expected reports on the economy a day earlier, including a worsening for U.S. manufacturing activity, an area hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation slowed enough for rate cuts to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\nTraders now bet on a 70% probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September according to data from CME Group. That's even though Powell said Wednesday such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nThe U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nU.S. stocks already appeared headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports.\n\nAmazon fell 8.8% after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected.\n\nIntel dropped 26.1%, its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts.\n\nApple held steadier, up 0.7%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.", "source": {"uri": "omaha.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Omaha.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-08-444796860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "16:42:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T16:42:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/dow-drops-760-points-and-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-amid-u-s-economy-worries-1.6989300", "title": "Dow drops 760 points, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 amid U.S. economy worries", "body": "Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 2.1 per cent in midday trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was reeling by 763 points, or 1.9 per cent, as of 12:20 p.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 2.4 per cent.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a global sell-off that began last week. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4 per cent for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nProfessional investors cautioned that some technical factors could be amplifying the action in markets, but the losses were still neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8 per cent lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2 per cent and bitcoin dropped below US$55,000 from more than US$61,000 on Friday.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped one per cent.\n\nThat's in part because traders began wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, briefly sank below 3.70 per cent during the morning from 3.88 per cent late Friday and from 5 per cent in April. It later recovered and pulled back to 3.93 per cent.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3 per cent doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nThe U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession within the next 12 months following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25 per cent probability of that, up from 15 per cent, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may also simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\n\"Markets tend to move higher like they're climbing stairs, and they go down like they're falling out a window,\" according to JJ Kinahan, CEO of IG North America. He chalks much of the recent worries to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself.\"\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero. Such a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nU.S. stocks pared their losses Monday after a report said growth for U.S. services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management. Treasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took sharp losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 2.8 per cent, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 3.7 per cent Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 6 per cent. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. The recent selling has trimmed Nvidia's gain for the year to nearly 104 per cent from 170 per cent in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies are the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could impact markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could affect the election itself.\n\nThe threat of a recession is likely to put U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris on the defensive. But slower growth could also further reduce inflation and force former U.S. president Donald Trump to pivot from his current focus on higher prices to outlining ways to revive the economy.", "source": Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing US employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected.\n\nThat was the latest piece of data on the US economy to come in weaker than expected, and it has all raised fears the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the US economy by too much for too long through high interest rates, in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nProfessional investors cautioned that some technical factors could be amplifying the action in markets, but the losses were still neck-snapping.\n\nSouth Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped below 55,000 dollars (\u00a343,000) from more than 61,000 dollars (\u00a347,800) on Friday.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1%.\n\nThat is in part because traders began wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on September 18.\n\nThe yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, briefly sank below 3.70% during the morning from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April. It later recovered and pulled back to 3.90%.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management.\n\n\"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like Covid, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nThe US economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nThe Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022 - being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession within the next 12 months after Friday's jobs report.\n\nBut he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances\".\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may also simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates.\n\nCritics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\n\"Markets tend to move higher like they're climbing stairs, and they go down like they're falling out a window,\" said JJ Kinahan, chief executive of IG North America.\n\nHe credits much of the recent worry to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself\".\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero.\n\nSuch a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nUS stocks pared their losses on Monday after a report said growth for US services businesses was a touch stronger than expected.\n\nGrowth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management.\n\nTreasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took sharp losses on the fears about a slowdown.\n\nThe small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 3.7%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel.\n\nApple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet.\n\nA set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 3.2% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that has become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 5%.\n\nAnalysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. The recent selling has trimmed Nvidia's gain for the year to nearly 106% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies are the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market.\n\nThe Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil.\n\nThat is adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming US elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could affect markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could affect the election itself.\n\nThe threat of a recession is likely to put vice president Kamala Harris on the defensive.\n\nBut slower growth could also further reduce inflation and force former president Donald Trump to change from his current focus on higher prices to outlining ways to revive the economy.", "source": {"uri": "basingstokegazette.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-08-444676535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:42:10", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:42:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T14:25:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/dow-drops-900-points-and-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-on-u-s/article_6b8cf448-388d-5ccd-a619-bdbb3aff65a8.html", "title": "Dow drops 900 points, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 on U.S. economy worries", "body": "Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 3.1% in morning trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 956 points, or 2.4%, as of 10:10 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 4%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped 9.5%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.4%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.81% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\nU.S. stocks pared their losses a bit Monday morning after a report said growth for U.S. services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 4.4%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 9.1%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 97% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could impact markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could also affect the election itself.\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach and Matt Ott contributed.\n\nMore from this {"uri": "2024-08-444654694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/dow-sinks-1-000-points-extending-a-global-rout-as-worries-deepen-about-a-us/article_6e0b7a1d-5e0c-531c-94c2-9cd0e3df9dbf.html", "title": "Dow sinks 1,000 points, extending a global rout, as worries deepen about a US economic slowdown", "body": "Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 4% in early trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 1,197 points, or 3%, as of 9:35 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 5.5% to pull it 15% below its record set last month.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3% and bitcoin dropped 12%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped nearly 2%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.74% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% chance of that, up from 10%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 6.8% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 11%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 92.7% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes. Nvidia, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon were the heaviest weights on the S&P 500.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach and Matt Ott contributed.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. {"uri": "8260491840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:09:36", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:09:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:08:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.thespec.com/business/dow-drops-760-points-and-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-amid-u-s/article_7210191d-48cb-507c-84b0-ff1bc611c7a2.html", "title": "Dow drops 760 points, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 amid U.S. economy worries", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 2.1% in midday trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was reeling by 763 points, or 1.9%, as of 12:20 p.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 2.4%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a global sell-off that began last week. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nProfessional investors cautioned that some technical factors could be amplifying the action in markets, but the losses were still neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped below $55,000 from more than $61,000 on Friday.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1%.\n\nThat's in part because traders began wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, briefly sank below 3.70% during the morning from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April. It later recovered and pulled back to 3.93%.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession within the next 12 months following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may also simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\n\"Markets tend to move higher like they're climbing stairs, and they go down like they're falling out a window,\" according to JJ Kinahan, CEO of IG North America. He chalks much of the recent worries to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself.\"\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero. Such a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nU.S. stocks pared their losses Monday after a report said growth for U.S. services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management. Treasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took sharp losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 2.8%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 3.7% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 6%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. The recent selling has trimmed Nvidia's gain for the year to nearly 104% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies are the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could impact markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could affect the election itself.\n\nThe threat of a recession is likely to put Vice President Kamala Harris on the defensive. But slower growth could also further reduce inflation and force former President Donald Trump to pivot from his current focus on higher prices to outlining ways to revive the economy.\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach, Matt Ott and Christopher Rugaber contributed.", "source": {"uri": "thespec.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thespec.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260330559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "15:10:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T15:10:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T15:10:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://mynorthwest.com/3973782/dow-drops-900-points-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-u-s-economy-worries/", "title": "Dow drops 900 points, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 on U.S. economy worries", "body": "The S&P 500 was down by 3.1% in morning trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 956 points, or 2.4%, as of 10:10 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 4%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nMore financial news: Bezos picks up a cool $5 billion selling Amazon stock\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank more than 2% and bitcoin dropped 9.5%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.4%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.81% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nMore financial news in Washington State: The other side of repealing the Washington capital gains tax\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% probability of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\nU.S. stocks pared their losses a bit Monday morning after a report said growth for U.S. services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 4.4%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nMore financial news: Amazon says this year's Prime Day was its biggest ever\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 9.1%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 97% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nWall Street has been concerned about how policies coming out of November could impact markets, but the sharp swings for stock prices could also affect the election itself.", "source": {"uri": "mynorthwest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "My Northwest"},
