He chalks much of the recent worries to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself.\"\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero. Such a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nUS stocks pared their losses Monday after a report said growth for US services businesses was a touch stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management. Treasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took sharp losses on the fears about a slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 3.7%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to records this year, even as high interest rates weighed down much of the rest of the stock market.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports that began with updates from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 3.2% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 5%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. The recent selling has trimmed Nvidia's gain for the year to nearly 106% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies are the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. {"uri": "8256134279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "14:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T14:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T14:39:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/money/global-sell-stocks-weak-jobs-33385193", "title": "Global sell-off for stocks with weak US jobs data fuelling recession fears", "body": "People pass the New York Stock Exchange on in New York. World shares have tumbled on Friday, with Japan's Nikkei 225 index slumping 5.8% as investors panicked over signs of weakness in the US economy\n\nA global sell-off for stocks has hit Wall Street again on Friday, with concerns about whether the US economy's growth can be sustained until the Federal Reserve reduces interest rates.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 1.6% in early trading, potentially marking its first consecutive loss of more than 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average had fallen by 481 points, or 1.2%, as of 9.35 Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite was down by 2.6%.\n\nA report revealing that hiring by US employers slowed significantly more than economists had predicted last month sent shockwaves through markets, causing both stocks and bond yields to plummet. This followed a series of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from the previous day, including a decline in US manufacturing activity, which has been one of the sectors most affected by high rates.\n\nJust a few days ago, US stock indexes experienced their best day in months after Fed Chair Jerome Powell gave the strongest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to interest rates to begin in September. Now, there are increasing concerns that the Fed maintained its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long in its efforts to curb inflation.\n\nA rate cut could take anywhere from several months to a year to impact the economy. \"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" Brian Jacobsen, the chief economist at Annex Wealth Management, remarked. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the usual cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nBefore the disheartening jobs report landed on Wall Street, US stocks seemed poised for losses. A slew of major tech companies delivered lacklustre profit reports, adding to the gloom that started last week with Tesla and Alphabet's figures.\n\nAmazon saw a 10% drop after reporting lower revenue than anticipated for the most recent quarter. The e-commerce behemoth also projected an operating profit for the summer that didn't meet analysts' forecasts.\n\nIntel took an even more significant hit, plunging 27.7%, as the chipmaker's profit fell massively below estimates for the latest quarter. It went as far as suspending its dividend and warning of expected losses in the third quarter, despite analyst predictions of profit.\n\nApple, however, managed a slight gain of 0.7%, having declared better-than-expected profit and revenue. Apple and a select group of other Big Tech stocks, known as the \" Magnificent Seven \", have been the primary drivers behind the S&P 500 setting numerous records this year, largely due to the hype surrounding artificial intelligence technology. However, their momentum took a hit last month amid concerns that their prices had soared too high and profit expectations had become too challenging to meet.\n\nIn a fortunate turn for Wall Street, other sectors of the stock market that had suffered due to high interest rates were making a comeback, particularly smaller companies. But they also took a tumble on Friday over fears that a fragile economy could dent their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index, which tracks smaller stocks, fell by 3.7%, outpacing the rest of the market. Over in the bond market, Treasury yields saw a sharp decline as traders increased their predictions for how much the Federal Reserve would slash interest rates at its next meeting in September. The yield on the 10-year Treasury dropped to 3.85% from 3.98% late Thursday, and down from 4.70% in April.\n\nDespite the widespread fear, some voices on Wall Street were still advocating for caution. \"While worries of a policy mistake are rising, one negative miss shouldn't lead to overreaction,\" said Lara Castleton, US head of portfolio construction and strategy at Janus Henderson Investors.\n\nShe highlights that the US economy continues to expand and inflation is on the decline. Not far behind its peak from a fortnight ago, the S&P 500 faces a dip. \"Equities selling off should be seen as a normal reaction, especially considering the high valuations in many pockets of the market. It's a good reminder for investors to focus on the earnings of companies going forward.\"\n\nOverseas markets are also feeling the pinch, with Japan's Nikkei 225 tumbling by 5.8%, regressing to January levels before last month's all-time high. The Bank of Japan's rate hike on Wednesday has triggered struggles for Japanese stocks, boosting the yen against the dollarbad news for exporters and tourism.\n\nWhile Chinese equities continue their slide this week, hope fades in response to insufficient governmental steps to bolster the economysmall-scale actions rather than substantial stimulus injections disappoint investors.\n\nStocks took a hit throughout much of Europe as well. Markets worldwide have been put through the wringer despite anticipated moves by central banks in Japan, the US, and England. With Japan bumping up its rate, the Fed holding steady, and the Bank of England cutting its main rate for the first time in over four years, it's been a tense week.\n\nCommodity prices have also experienced turbulence, with oil prices skyrocketing following the assassinations of leaders from Hamas and Hezbollah, stoking fears that conflict in the Middle East could escalate into a broader war. However, prices receded on Thursday and Friday due to concerns about the economy.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8256587258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "21:00:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T21:00:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T21:00:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/weak-us-jobs-report-ignites-a-sell-off-on-wall-st/article_4a327432-510e-11ef-b206-43d3092a9de3.html", "title": "Weak US jobs report ignites a sell-off on Wall St.", "body": "NEW YORK -- Stocks tumbled to close the week Aug. 2 on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 1.8 percent for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1 percent since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.5 percent, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4 percent as a global financial sell-off whipped all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than expected sent fear through markets, with both stocks and bond yields dropping sharply.\n\nIt followed a batch of weaker-than-expected reports on the economy from a day earlier, including one about the softening state of U.S. manufacturing activity, which has been one of the areas hurt most by high rates.\n\nIt was just a couple days ago that U.S. stock indexes jumped to their best day in months after the head of the Federal Reserve gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\n\"The Fed is seizing defeat from the jaws of victory,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Economic momentum has slowed so much that a rate cut in September will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than\" the traditional cut of a quarter of a percentage point \"to avert a recession.\"\n\nTraders are now betting on a 70 percent probability that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. That's even though Jerome Powell, the central bank's chairman, said Wednesday that such a deep reduction is \"not something we're thinking about right now.\"\n\nThe U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it's walking since it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen.\n\nWhile refusing to claim victory on either the jobs or the inflation fronts on Wednesday, before the discouraging economic reports hit, Powell said Fed officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after hiking its main rate so high.\n\n\"Certainly today's job data feeds the weakening economy narrative, but I believe the market is overreacting at this point and pricing too much in on rate cuts at this stage,\" said Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management. \"Yes, the economy is weakening, but I am not convinced there is enough evidence that the data so far is a death knell for the economy.\"\n\nMarkets likely panicked in part Friday because when the unemployment ticked up to 4.3 percent last month -- the highest since October 2021 -- it set off the so-called Sahm Rule.\n\nNamed for former Fed economist Claudia Sahm, it holds that a recession is almost always underway already if the three-month average unemployment rate rises by half a percentage point from its low of the past year. It's been triggered in every U.S. recession since 1970.\n\nBut Sahm herself doubts that a recession is \"imminent.'' Speaking before the numbers came out Friday, she said: \"If the Sahm Rule were to trigger, it would join the ever-growing group of indicators, rules of thumb, that weren't up to the task.''\n\nToday's Top Headlines\n\nStory continues below\n\nAn abandoned 120-foot US Navy ship is stuck in a Johns Island creek. How did it get there? A customer wrote a negative review. This Murrells Inlet restaurant is now suing her. Florence teachers dressed as Border Patrol agents as part of school event. Now they're under fire. Tropical wave changes direction. Is South Carolina still in its path? Johns Island's first luxury resort, restaurant and venue welcomes guests Lindsey Graham says Trump erred when he questioned Kamala Harris' identity as a Black woman New Charleston-area meat-and-three restaurant is now open Grace period is over for 'Carolina Squat' truck in SC. How many tickets have been issued? More than a dozen former and current inmates, corrections officers charged with criminal conspiracy Court date set for Alex Murdaugh's appeal of 40-year federal prison sentence\n\nU.S. stocks had already appeared to be headed for losses Friday before the disappointing jobs report thudded onto Wall Street.\n\nSeveral big technology companies turned in underwhelming profit reports, which continued a mostly dispiriting run that began last week with results from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon fell 8.8 percent after reporting weaker revenue for the latest quarter than expected. The retail and tech giant also gave a forecast for operating profit for the summer that fell short of expectations.\n\nIntel dropped even more, 26.1 percent, for its worst day in 50 years, after the chip company's profit for the latest quarter fell well short of forecasts. It also suspended its dividend and forecast a loss for the third quarter, when analysts were expecting a profit.\n\nApple held steadier, rising slightly after reporting stronger profits and sales.\n\nApple and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" were the main reasons the S&P 500 set dozens of records this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10 percent below its record set last month into what traders call \"correction\" territory.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, other areas of the stock market beaten down by high interest rates began rebounding sharply last month when tech stocks were regressing, particularly smaller companies. But they tumbled, too, Friday on worries that a fragile economy could undercut their profits. The Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks dropped 3.5 percent, more than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the bond market, Treasury yields fell sharply as traders forecasted deeper cuts to rates coming from the Federal Reserve. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79%, down from 4.70% in April.\n\nIn stock markets abroad, Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8 percent. It's been struggling since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and hurt tourism.\n\nCommodity prices also had a rough ride this week. Oil prices leaped after the killings of leaders of Hamas and Hezbollah fueled fears that a widening conflict in the Middle East could disrupt the flow of crude.\n\nBut prices fell back Thursday and Friday on worries that a weakening economy would burn less fuel. A barrel of benchmark U.S. crude dropped back below $74 Friday after coming into the week above $77.\n\n___\n\nAP Business Writers Matt Ott and Elaine Kurtenbach contributed.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-08-444636041", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:06:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:06:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T10:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/dow-drops-nearly-1-000-and-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-on-u-s-economy-fears-1.6989300", "title": "Dow drops nearly 1,000, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 on U.S. economy fears", "body": "Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 3.1 per cent in early trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 996 points, or 2.5 per cent, as of 9:50 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 3.8 per cent.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4 per cent for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8 per cent lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3 per cent and bitcoin dropped 12 per cent.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.6 per cent.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.79 per cent from 3.88 per cent late Friday and from 5 per cent in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3 per cent doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25 per cent chance of that, up from 15 per cent, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5 per cent, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 4.6 per cent Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 8.3 per cent. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 98.7 per cent from 170 per cent in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8256993424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-03", "time": "06:07:45", "dateTime": "2024-08-03T06:07:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-03T06:05:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://en.paperblog.com/stock-market-today-dow-drops-600-on-weak-jobs-data-as-a-global-sell-off-whips-back-to-wall-street-7837609/", "title": "Stock Market Today: Dow Drops 600 on Weak Jobs Data as a Global Sell-off Whips Back to Wall Street - Paperblog", "body": "Stocks tumbled on Friday as investors worried that a stubbornly sturdy jobs market might be pushing the US economy towards a difficult downturn as the Federal Reserve raises interest rates to rein in inflation.\n\nThe S P 500 fell 1.8 per cent for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1 per cent since April, the Dow Jones Industrial Average plunged 610 points, or 1.5 per cent, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 2.4 per cent as a sell-off in stocks lashed itself all the way around the world back to Wall Street.\n\nA then-much-more-than-expected slowdown in hiring by US companies last month sent markets reeling as investors worried about the impact of slowing economic growth. US stock prices and bond yields plummeted in the aftermath of the report, days after a raft of disappointing US economic reports a day earlier, including a further deterioration in US factory activity, which has been one of the areas hit hardest by high rates.\n\nJust a couple days ago, US stock indexes soared to their best day in months when Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest sign that, with inflation finally cooling, rate cuts could come as soon as next month.\n\nNow, fears that the Fed has held its key interest rate too high for too long are growing. A rate cut would make it cheaper for US households and companies to borrow, a shot in the arm for the economy, but it takes months to a year for the effects to be fully felt.\n\n'The Fed is snatching defeat from the jaws of victory,' said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management: 'Economic momentum has slowed so much that a September cut will be too little and too late. They'll have to do something bigger than' a quarter point to avert a recession.\n\nSpeculators see a 70 per cent chance that the Fed will lower its benchmark rate by 50 basis points in September even if Powell said Wednesday 'that's not something we're thinking about right now'. -- Data from CME Group shows that traders are betting on a 70 per cent probability that the US central bank will reduce its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, even though the Fed's new boss Powell said Wednesday that such a deep reduction 'is not something we're thinking about right now'. --\n\nAfter all, the US economy is still growing, and a recession is hardly guaranteed. From the moment it began jacking up rates in March 2022, the Fed has been telling us it's walking a tightrope: too much and you choke the economy, too little and you give the inflation problem more to feed on.\n\nWhile refusing to declare victory on either the jobs front or on inflation - which was before Thursday's dismal economic news - Powell said Fed policymakers 'have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness' in the job market following the Fed's aggressive hike of its key rate.\n\n'Yes, that's very supportive of the narrative that the economy is weakening. But I think the market is overdoing it at this point and people are freaking out too much about the now-' Nate Thooft, senior portfolio manager at Manulife Investment Management, told the Financial Times. 'Yes, the economy is weakening, but I don't think the evidence is there yet that the data to date is a sure sign of the death of the economy.'\n\nStocks in the US had looked ready for a losing session anyway Friday before the ugly jobs report landed on Wall Street.\n\nThere, a long list of big tech firms posted lacklustre earnings reports - a continuation of a generally unpleasant run that began last week with numbers from Tesla and Alphabet.\n\nAmazon tumbled 8.8 per cent after the retail and tech behemoth provided weaker-than-expected revenue for the latest quarter and issued a profit forecast for the summer that similarly failed to live up to analysts' expectations.\n\nIntel fell yet more, 26.1 per cent - its worst day in half a century - after the second largest chip company by market value reported that its profit for the latest quarter missed estimates. It also announced that it would, reported the Los Angeles Times, 'suspend its quarterly dividend and forecast a loss for the third quarter, when analysts had projected a profit'.\n\nApple held steadier, up 0.7%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nApple and six other Big Tech stocks in what Wall Street calls the 'Magnificent Seven' have powered the S \u0333P \u0333 500 to dozens of records this year on growing enthusiasm about artificial-intelligence technology. But that wind at their backs suddenly died down in September as investors grown fearful that it would hurt take prices too high.\n\nFriday's tech-sector selloff sent the Nasdaq composite down 10 per cent from its all-time peak set last month - a decline traditionally called a 'correction'.\n\nHelpfully for Wall Street, sectors of the stock market crushed by high interest rates began rebounding hard last month even as tech stocks were spectacularly retreating, especially smaller companies. But they too swooned on Friday as worries took hold that a weak economy might derail their profits.\n\nThe Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks lost 3.5 per cent, worse than the rest of the market.\n\nIn the end, the S&P 500 dropped 100.12 points to 5,346.56, the Dow came down 610.71 to 39,737.26, and the Nasdaq composite fell 417.98 to 16,776.16.\n\nYields on Treasuries sank in the bond market, with traders anticipating further rate cuts by the US Federal Reserve. The yield on the 10-year Treasury dropped from 3.98 per cent late Thursday, and from 4.70 per cent in April.\n\nOverseas, stocks in Japan's Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8 per cent. It's been struggling after the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday, a move that boosted the Japanese yen against the US dollar and could erode profits for exporters. It could also deflate a boom in tourism from abroad.\n\nChinese stocks tumbled as investors digested the government's latest efforts to revive demand through a raft of piecemeal measures rather than the hoped-for injections of broader stimulus, while stock indexes fell by more than 1 per cent range across much of Europe.\n\nCommodity prices also had a rollercoaster ride this week: a spike in the price of oil came after the killings of two leaders of terrorist middle eastern groups, Hamas and Hezbollah, rejuvenated fears of a wider Middle East conflict strangling the world's oil supply.\n\nHowever, prices retreated Thursday and Friday as investors worried that a slowing economy would burn less crude. A barrel of benchmark US crude on Friday again fell below $74 after opening the week above $77.", "source": {"uri": "en.paperblog.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Paperblog"}, "authors": [], Manufacturing has been one of areas of the economy hurt most by high rates, and the report from the Institute for Supply Management helped extinguish what had been gains for U.S. stock indexes early {"uri": "8260570289", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "18:19:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T18:19:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T18:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/investing/article-heres-what-to-know-about-falling-financial-markets-and-how-we-got-here/", "title": "Here's what to know about falling financial markets and how we got here", "body": "Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10 per cent decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12 per cent, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2 per cent and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2 per cent. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nHere's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2 per cent target. Part of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labour market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signalled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8 per cent in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple AAPL-Q fell 5 per cent Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia NVDA-Q lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7 per cent Monday.\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2 per cent in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260235744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:06:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:06:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T14:05:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/aug/05/dow-sinks-1000-points-extending-a-global-rout-as-w/", "title": "Dow sinks 1,000 points, extending a global rout, as worries deepen about a U.S. economic slowdown", "body": "Mary Altaffer / AP\n\nIn this Jan. 3, 2020, photo, the Wall St. street sign is framed by American flags flying outside the New York Stock Exchange in New York.\n\nBy Stan Choe, Associated Press\n\nMonday, Aug. 5, 2024 | 6:59 a.m.\n\nNEW YORK -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 4% in early trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 1,197 points, or 3%, as of 9:35 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 5.5% to pull it 15% below its record set last month.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3% and bitcoin dropped 12%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped nearly 2%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.74% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% chance of that, up from 10%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 6.8% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 11%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 92.7% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes. Nvidia, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon were the heaviest weights on the S&P 500.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\n___\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach and Matt Ott {"uri": "8259295015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "02:04:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T02:04:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T02:01:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/business/japans-nikkei-index-plunges-nearly-7-as-global-sell-offs-resume-101722822543274.html", "title": "Japan's Nikkei index plunges nearly 7% as global sell-offs resume", "body": "The Nikkei had shed more than 2,400 points to 33,488.08 about a half-hour after opening. By about an hour after trading began, the index was down 5.3%, or about 1,900 points, at 34,010.69.\n\nThe market's broader TOPIX index fell as much as 7.8% before recovering to trade down 6.6%.\n\nStocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to tame inflation.=\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than expected has convulsed financial markets, vanquishing the euphoria that had taken the Nikkei to all-times highs of over 42,000 in recent weeks.\n\n\"To put it mildly, the spike in volatility-of-volatility is a spectacle that underlines just how jittery markets have become,\" Stephen Innes of SPI Asset Management said in a commentary. \"The real question now looms: Can the typical market reflex to sell volatility or buy the market dip prevail over the deep-seated anxiety brought on by this sudden and sharp recession scare?\"\n\nElsewhere in Asia, Taiwan's Taiex saw the largest decline, sinking 5.7%. Market heavyweight and omputer chip maker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. lost 5.3%.\n\nHong Kong's Hang Seng index lost 2.1% to 16,945.51 and the S&P/ASX 200 in Australia declined 1.3% to 7,725.40. South Korea's Kospi declined 3.4% to 2,570.64.\n\nOn Friday, the S&P 500 sank 1.8% for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as stocks retreated around the world and back to Wall Street.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10% below its record set last month. That level of drop is what traders call a \"correction.\"\n\nThe rout began just a couple days after U.S. stock indexes had jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long, raising risks of a recession in the world's largest economy. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\nWorries over weakness in the U.S. economy and volatile markets have rippled around the world, even though the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nThe Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8% on Friday. It has struggled since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday and is now at about the level it was when the year began.\n\nThe sell-offs on Friday and Monday were among the worst ever for the index, which saw its biggest rout during the market meltdowns of Black Monday in October 1987.\n\nThe modest rate hike, to just 0.25% from 0.1%, pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and deflate a boom in tourism. But worries over the U.S. economy seem to be a larger factor driving investors to dump stocks.\n\nEarly Monday, the dollar was trading at 145.50 yen. That's sharply below its level of over 160 yen a few weeks ago.\n\nChinese stocks fell Friday as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8260525308", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:39:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:39:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:38:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/why-financial-markets-are-falling-and-how-we-got-here", "title": "Why financial markets are falling and how we got here", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nWATCH: Economist says Federal Reserve too slow to cut interest rates and weakening the economy\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10% decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12%, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2% and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2%. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nHere's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nInflation and central banks\n\nThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2% target. Part of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labor market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signaled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nAnxiety over the U.S. economy\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8% in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nBig Tech\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7% Monday.\n\nJapan's slump\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2% in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", {"uri": "2024-08-444803136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "16:49:30", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T16:49:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T12:37:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/technology/articles/2024-08-05/financial-markets-around-the-globe-are-falling-heres-what-to-know-about-how-we-got-here", "title": "Financial Markets Around the Globe Are Falling. Here's What to Know About How We Got Here", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10% decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12%, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2% and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2%. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nHere's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nInflation and central banks\n\nThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2% target. Part of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labor market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signaled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nAnxiety over the U.S. economy\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8% in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nBig Tech\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7% Monday.\n\nJapan's slump\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2% in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8260215961", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "13:56:44", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T13:56:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T13:52:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/dow-sinks-1-000-points-extending-a-global-rout-as-worries-deepen-about-a-us/article_a59a9def-cc27-5a56-a35f-ffe0f9779bed.html", "title": "Dow sinks 1,000 points, extending a global rout, as worries deepen about a US economic slowdown", "body": "FILE - People pass the New York Stock Exchange July 10, 2024, in New York. World shares began trading mixed on Monday, July 15, 2024, after China reported that its economy expanded at a lower-than-forecast 4.7% annual pace in the last quarter.\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 4% in early trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 1,197 points, or 3%, as of 9:35 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 5.5% to pull it 15% below its record set last month.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3% and bitcoin dropped 12%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped nearly 2%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.74% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% chance of that, up from 10%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 6.8% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 11%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 92.7% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes. Nvidia, Apple, Microsoft and Amazon were the heaviest weights on the S&P 500.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach and Matt Ott contributed.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "stan_choe@eagletribune.com", "name": "Stan Choe", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "2024-08-444844072", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:36:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:36:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:36:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.koat.com/article/financial-markets-around-the-globe-are-falling-heres-what-to-know/61793835", "title": "Financial markets around the globe are falling. Here's what to know about how we got here", "body": "Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.For most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.By June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.That confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.On Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10% decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12%, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2% and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2%. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.Traders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.Here's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:Inflation and central banksThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2% target. Part of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labor market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.Investors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signaled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.Anxiety over the U.S. economyThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8% in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.On Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.Big TechWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.This handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.Apple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7% Monday.Japan's slumpThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2% in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.Share prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.Analysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.The yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.\n\nMarkets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10% decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12%, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2% and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2%. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nHere's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nInflation and central banks\n\nThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2% target. Part of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labor market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signaled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nAnxiety over the U.S. economy\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8% in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nBig Tech\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7% Monday.\n\nJapan's slump\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2% in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.", "source": {"uri": "koat.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KOAT 7"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@koat.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", The S&P 500 fell 2.4% Friday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 608 points, and the Nasdaq composite fell 3.4%. A report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than expected sent fear through markets. Intel helped lead the market lower after reporting weaker-than-expected profits and suspending its dividend.
