{"uri": "8260481081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:07:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:07:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T16:59:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13711161/Financial-markets-globe-falling-Heres-know-got-here.html", "title": "Financial markets around the globe are falling. Here's what to know...", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) - Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan\u00b4s Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world\u00b4s largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan\u00b4s markets.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10% decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12%, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2% and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2%. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nTrader Vincent Napolitano works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)\n\nHere\u00b4s a look at what\u00b4s driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nThough the Fed hasn\u00b4t raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2% target. Part of the Fed\u00b4s goal was to cool a red-hot labor market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signaled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8% in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett\u00b4s Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7% Monday.\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2% in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.\n\nSpecialist James Denaro, right, works at his post on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Monday, Aug. 5, 2024. Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\nWorries over weakness in the U.S. economy and volatile markets have rippled around the world, even though the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nThe Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8% on Friday. {"uri": "8259280090", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "01:42:43", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T01:42:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T01:41:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/2024/08/04/japans-nikkei-225-index-plunges-nearly-7-as-global-sell-offs-resume/", "title": "Japan's Nikkei 225 index plunges nearly 7% as global sell-offs resume - KION546", "body": "BANGKOK (AP) -- Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index plunged 6.7% early Monday before recovering some lost ground, extending sell-offs that began last week.\n\nThe Nikkei had shed more than 2,400 points to 33,488.08 about a half-hour after opening. By about an hour after trading began, the index was down 5.3%, or about 1,900 points, at 34,010.69.\n\nThe market's broader TOPIX index fell as much as 7.8% before recovering to trade down 6.6%.\n\nStocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to tame inflation.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than expected has convulsed financial markets, vanquishing the euphoria that had taken the Nikkei to all-times highs of over 42,000 in recent weeks.\n\n\"To put it mildly, the spike in volatility-of-volatility is a spectacle that underlines just how jittery markets have become,\" Stephen Innes of SPI Asset Management said in a commentary. \"The real question now looms: Can the typical market reflex to sell volatility or buy the market dip prevail over the deep-seated anxiety brought on by this sudden and sharp recession scare?\"\n\nElsewhere in Asia, Taiwan's Taiex saw the largest decline, sinking 5.7%. Market heavyweight and computer chip maker Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. lost 5.3%.\n\nHong Kong's Hang Seng index lost 2.1% to 16,945.51 and the S&P/ASX 200 in Australia declined 1.3% to 7,725.40. South Korea's Kospi declined 3.4% to 2,570.64.\n\nOn Friday, the S&P 500 sank 1.8% for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as stocks retreated around the world and back to Wall Street.\n\nFriday's losses for tech stocks dragged the Nasdaq composite 10% below its record set last month. That level of drop is what traders call a \"correction.\"\n\nThe rout began just a couple days after U.S. stock indexes had jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long, raising risks of a recession in the world's largest economy. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\nWorries over weakness in the U.S. economy and volatile markets have rippled around the world, even though the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nThe Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8% on Friday. It has struggled since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday and is now at about the level it was when the year began.\n\nThe sell-offs on Friday and Monday were among the worst ever for the index, which saw its biggest rout during the market meltdowns of Black Monday in October 1987.\n\nThe modest rate hike, to just 0.25% from 0.1%, pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and deflate a boom in tourism. But worries over the U.S. economy seem to be a larger factor driving investors to dump stocks.\n\nEarly Monday, the dollar was trading at 145.50 yen. That's sharply below its level of over 160 yen a few weeks ago.\n\nChinese stocks fell Friday as investors registered disappointment with the government's latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.", "source": {"uri": "kion546.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8260263574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:25:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:25:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T14:24:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/08/05/business/japans-nikkei-225-stock-index-sinks-8-percent-worst-losses-since-1987/", "title": "Dow drops nearly 1,000, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 on US economy fears - The Boston Globe", "body": "The drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4 percent for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing US employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the US economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the US economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8 percent lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3 percent and bitcoin dropped 12 percent.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.6 percent.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.79 percent from 3.88 percent late Friday and from 5 percent in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3 percent doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the US economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25 percent chance of that, up from 15 percent, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5 percent, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 4.6 percent Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 8.3 percent. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 98.7 percent from 170 percent in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming US elections could further scramble things.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", By about an hour after trading began, the index was down 5.3%, or about 1,900 points, at 34,010.69.\n\nStocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to tame inflation.\n\nA report showing hiring by U.S. employers slowed last month by much more than expected has convulsed financial markets, vanquishing the euphoria that had taken the Nikkei to all-times highs of over 42,000 in recent weeks.\n\nThe S&P 500 sank 1.8% on Friday for its first back-to-back losses of at least 1% since April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 610 points, or 1.5%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.4% as stocks retreated around the world and back to Wall Street.\n\nThe rout began just a couple days after U.S. stock indexes had jumped to their best day in months after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell gave the clearest indication yet that inflation has slowed enough for cuts to rates to begin in September.\n\nA board above the trading floor shows the closing number for the Dow Jones industrial average, at the New York Stock Exchange, Friday, Aug. 2, 2024. Stocks tumbled Friday on worries the U.S. economy could be cracking under the weight of high interest rates meant to whip inflation.(AP Photo/Richard Drew)\n\nNow, worries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long, raising risks of a recession in the world's largest economy. A rate cut would make it easier for U.S. households and companies to borrow money and boost the economy, but it could take months to a year for the full effects to filter through.\n\nWorries over weakness in the U.S. economy and volatile markets have rippled around the world, even though the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from a certainty.\n\nThe Nikkei 225 dropped 5.8% on Friday. It has struggled since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. The hike pushed up the value of the Japanese yen against the U.S. dollar, which could hurt profits for exporters and deflate a boom in tourism.\n\nEarly Monday, the dollar was trading at 145.50 yen. That's sharply below its level of over 160 yen a few weeks ago.\n\nChinese stocks fell Friday as investors registered disappointment with the government\u00b4s latest efforts to spur growth through various piecemeal measures, instead of hoped-for infusions of broader stimulus, while stock indexes dropped by more than 1% across much of Europe.\n\nFILE - People pass the New York Stock Exchange on July 31, 2024 in New York. {"uri": "8260227875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:01:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:01:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T14:00:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/wires/business/dow-drops-nearly-1-000-and-japanese-stocks-suffer-worst-crash-since-1987-on-u/article_e458c8e1-4bda-5445-871e-8f56cafd5233.html", "title": "Dow drops nearly 1,000, and Japanese stocks suffer worst crash since 1987 on U.S. economy fears", "body": "NEW YORK (AP) -- Nearly everything on Wall Street is tumbling Monday as fear about a slowing U.S. economy worsens and sets off another sell-off for financial markets around the world.\n\nThe S&P 500 was down by 3.1% in early trading, coming off its worst week in more than three months. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 996 points, or 2.5%, as of 9:50 a.m. Eastern time, and the Nasdaq composite slid 3.8%.\n\nThe drops were just the latest in a sell-off that swept the Earth. Japan's Nikkei 225 helped start Monday by plunging 12.4% for its worst day since the Black Monday crash of 1987.\n\nIt was the first chance for traders in Tokyo to react to Friday's report showing U.S. employers slowed their hiring last month by much more than economists expected. That was the latest piece of data on the U.S. economy to come in weaker than expected, and it's all raised fear the Federal Reserve has pressed the brakes on the U.S. economy by too much for too long through high interest rates in hopes of stifling inflation.\n\nLosses elsewhere in the world were nearly as neck-snapping. South Korea's Kospi index careened 8.8% lower, stock markets across Europe sank roughly 3% and bitcoin dropped 12%.\n\nEven gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped 1.6%.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.79% from 3.88% late Friday and from 5% in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasurys and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least by a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the U.S. economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25% chance of that, up from 15%, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5%, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 4.6% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 8.3%. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. It has trimmed its gain for the year to 98.7% from 170% in the middle of June.\n\nBecause the Magnificent Seven companies have grown to be the market's biggest by market value, the movements for their stocks carry much more weight on the S&P 500 and other indexes.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nWorries outside corporate profits, interest rates and the economy are also weighing on the market. The Israel-Hamas war may be worsening, which beyond its human toll could also cause sharp swings for the price of oil. That's adding to broader worries about potential hotspots around the world, while upcoming U.S. elections could further scramble things.\n\n___\n\nAP Business Writers Elaine Kurtenbach and Matt Ott {"uri": "8260484011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:05:08", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:05:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:02:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-financial-markets-around-the-globe-are-falling-heres-what-to-know-about-how-we-got-here-6166396.html", "title": "World News | Financial Markets Around the Globe Are Falling. Here's What to Know About How We Got Here | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on World at LatestLY. Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing US economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nNew York, Aug 5 (AP) Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing US economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy US economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nAlso Read | Bangladesh Unrest: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee Appeals to People To Maintain Peace in State.\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as USD 3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S and P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the US Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the US economy, the world's largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a US recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.\n\nAlso Read | Bangladesh Unrest: Indian Cultural Centre Vandalised by Unruly Mob, 4 Hindu Temples Suffer Minor Damages Across Country.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10 per cent decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12 per cent, its worst drop since 1987.\n\nBy midday in the US, the S and P 500 was down 2.2 per cent and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2 per cent. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the US are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nHere's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nInflation and central banks\n\nThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the US central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2 per cent target.\n\nPart of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labour market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the US economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signalled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nAnxiety over the US economy\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the US economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8 per cent in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by US employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nBig Tech\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S and P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple fell 5 per cent on Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than USD 238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7 per cent on Monday.\n\nJapan's slump\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2 per cent in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one US dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring. Here's what to know about how we got here", "body": "The Assoicated Press\n\nNEW YORK (AP) -- Markets on Wall Street and around the world are in a mini-panic. Worried about a slowing U.S. economy, investors sent the market in Japan to its worst day in decades and have sliced billions in market value off some of the world's biggest technology companies. They've turned a relatively calm year in markets on its head.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nBy June Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nOld Pink fire was due to arson, investigators find; person of interest identified Caesars Sportsbook promo code PLAYS1000 for NFL Hall Of Fame Game: $1,000 bonus for Bears vs. Texans 'Time is an enemy': Costco unlikely before 2026, Station Twelve a question mark and Boulevard Mall languishes Camp observations: Bills run game, pass defense show out at Highmark practice Price hike: Seat prices doubling at new Bills stadium for some club season ticket holders Wegmans loses its crown as top supermarket Bills camp observations: Coach Sean McDermott concerned about number of injuries PolitiFact: Tenney claims that Biden executive order requires federal employees to break law Alan Pergament: As of September, all three local broadcast affiliates will have 7 p.m. newscasts Jiri Kulich must 'tear up the league' with Amerks before his Sabres call comes 'A dangerous situation': Safety fixes sought after Tonawanda crash kills teen bicyclist Police take shooting suspects into custody after chase over Skyway Bills punting competition ends as team adds another safety to roster NJ developer plans overhaul of Gateway Building property in Hamburg Sabres Mailbag: Can Lindy Ruff make Buffalo one of NHL's top defensive teams?\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while. Weak readings on the job market, manufacturing and construction last week sparked worries about a U.S. recession and criticism that the Fed waited too long to cut rates. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan has started raising rates, causing turmoil in Japan's markets.\n\nOn Friday, the Nasdaq composite went into a correction, which is a 10% decline from its most recent high. On Monday, the Nikkei plunged more than 12%, its worst drop since 1987. By midday in the U.S., the S&P 500 was down 2.2% and, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had dropped 2%. Oil and other commodities prices fell because of the economic worries.\n\nTraders in the U.S. are betting the Federal Reserve will have to cut rates by half a percentage point in September instead of the usual quarter point. Some are calling for an emergency rate cut. However, there are opposing voices saying the sell-off is actually a good thing because stock prices had risen too high.\n\nHere's a look at what's driving the turbulence in markets:\n\nInflation and central banks\n\nThough the Fed hasn't raised its benchmark rate in a year, interest rates remain at more than two-decade highs after the U.S. central bank raised them 11 times beginning in 2022 in an effort to get inflation down to its 2% target. Part of the Fed's goal was to cool a red-hot labor market that rebounded after the pandemic recession with the rest of the U.S. economy.\n\nInvestors thought the Fed and other central banks were on track, even though inflation remained somewhat above their targets. The European Central Bank and the Bank of England cut once, and the Fed has signaled it was prepared to start cutting rates in September.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnxiety over the U.S. economy\n\nThere had been some pockets of weakness in the U.S. economy, particularly spending by lower-income Americans, but overall the economy still grew at a rate of 2.8% in the second quarter. Then came last week's economic reports.\n\nOn Friday, the government's monthly report on the job market showed a significant slowdown in hiring by U.S. employers. Worries that the Fed may have kept the brakes on the economy too long spread through the markets. Reports on manufacturing and construction were also weak.\n\nBig Tech\n\nWhile technology stocks have been the biggest winners in the market's runup this year, members of the highly influential group of stocks known as the \" Magnificent Seven \" underwhelmed investors in their latest earnings reports.\n\nThis handful of Big Tech stocks drove the S&P 500 to dozens of records this year, in part due to the frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. But their momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for their profit gains had grown too difficult to meet, particularly with regard to artificial intelligence.\n\nApple fell 5% Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker. Nvidia lost more than $238 billion in market value Thursday and Friday and the stock was down another 7% Monday.\n\nJapan's slump\n\nThe Nikkei suffered its worst two-day decline ever, dropping 18.2% in the last two trading sessions. The wave of selling hit all sorts of companies, including Toyota, Honda and computer chip maker Tokyo Electron.\n\nShare prices have fallen in Tokyo since the Bank of Japan raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday.\n\nAnalysts said factor one factor contributing to the falling share prices was carry trades. That when investors borrow money from a country with low interest rates and a relatively weak currency, like Japan, and invest those funds in places that will yield a high return. But the higher interest rates, plus a stronger Japanese yen, could force investors to selling stocks to repay those loans.\n\nThe yen rose to 143.25 for one U.S. dollar on Wednesday morning. It had topped 160 in the spring.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. weekly.\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "buffalonews.com", {"uri": "2024-08-445000232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "21:20:00", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T21:20:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:11:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/aug/5/stocks-plummet-worldwide-as-worries-mount-that-us-/", "title": "Stocks plummet worldwide as worries mount that U.S. economy has hit the brakes", "body": "A swift global panic struck financial markets Monday, triggering stock sell-offs around the world amid fears that the U.S. economy is slowing into recession territory in the presidential election year.\n\nWall Street had its second straight day of sharp losses, after seven months of relatively steady growth this year. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite fell 3.4%, the S&P 500 was down by 2.9% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.9%.\n\nEarlier Monday, Japan's Nikkei 225 plunged 12.4% for its worst day since the crash of 1987. South Korea's benchmark Kospi lost 8%. The losses cascaded through Europe, with London's FTSE 100 down 2% in its worst day of trading since January.\n\nTech stocks in the U.S. sustained some of the heaviest losses as investors worried that spending on AI might not bring results soon. Nvidia Inc. lost more than 6%, Apple was down 4.4% as Berkshire Hathaway cut its stake in the iPhone maker, and Microsoft fell 3.4%.\n\nInvestors worldwide reacted to the Labor Department's report of weaker-than-expected hiring in July. It prompted concerns that the Federal Reserve has kept interest rates too high for too long to bring down inflation that soared to a 40-year high under the Biden-Harris administration. The jobless rate in July rose to 4.3%, the highest since October 2021.\n\nEconomic anxieties highlighted by the massive sell-off are rapidly gaining renewed prominence in the presidential campaign.\n\nPresident Biden, returning to the White House Monday from a weekend at his home in Delaware, didn't respond to reporters' shouted questions about the stock market. Vice President Kamala Harris, who quickly captured the Democratic nomination after Mr. Biden dropped out of the race, was huddled in meetings with advisers as she prepared to announce her selection of a running mate.\n\nHer opponent, former President Donald Trump, blamed Ms. Harris and the president, signaling the renewed importance of the economy and high prices as major campaign themes.\n\n\"Of course there is a massive market downturn,\" Mr. Trump said on social media. \"Voters have a choice -- Trump prosperity, or the Kamala crash & great depression of 2024.\"\n\nSen. Tom Cotton, Arkansas Republican, posted on X: \"If you think the economy is bad today, putting a San Francisco socialist in charge would make it much worse.\"\n\nMs. Harris has been trying to calibrate her economic message as she takes the reins of Democrats' campaign. \"Bidenomics\" has not sat well with voters who, despite a good jobs picture for the last few years, have faced punishing price increases that canceled out wage gains.\n\nSen. J.D. Vance of Ohio, the GOP vice presidential nominee, will hold a campaign event in Philadelphia on Tuesday hours before Ms. Harris introduces her running mate to Democratic voters in the city. The Trump campaign gave a preview of Mr. Vance's visit, saying, \"The stock market is crashing because of weak and failed Kamala Harris' policies ... In weak, failed, and dangerously liberal Kamala Harris' America, families are struggling to afford the basics and stay safe.\"\n\nThe Trump campaign said Pennsylvania families have had to pay an average of $958 more per month due to higher prices.\n\nOn Wall Street, some traders began wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Fed will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The central bank took no action on rates at its meeting last month.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3% doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\nSome of Wall Street's recent declines may also simply be air coming out of a stock market that romped to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial intelligence technology and hopes for coming cuts to interest rates. Critics have been saying for a while that the stock market looked expensive after prices rose faster than corporate profits.\n\n\"Markets tend to move higher like they're climbing stairs, and they go down like they're falling out a window,\" according to J.J. Kinahan, CEO of IG North America. He chalks much of the recent worries to euphoria around AI subsiding and \"a market that was ahead of itself.\"\n\nProfessional investors also pointed to the Bank of Japan's move last week to raise its main interest rate from nearly zero. Such a move helps boost the value of the Japanese yen, but it could also force traders to scramble out of deals where they borrowed money for virtually no cost in Japan and invested it elsewhere around the world.\n\nThere was some positive economic news Monday, with a report saying growth for U.S. services businesses was slightly stronger than expected. Growth was led by businesses in the arts, entertainment and recreation businesses, along with accommodations and food services, according to the Institute for Supply Management. Treasury yields also pared their drops following the better-than-expected data.\n\nOthers pointed to second-quarter growth of 2.8% in the U.S. which was much stronger than expected.\n\nFor most of the year, investors worldwide drove stock markets higher, convinced that central banks were successfully, if haltingly, getting inflation under control, and buoyed by a healthy U.S. economy and the promise of artificial intelligence.\n\nBy June, Nvidia, the leader in AI chipmaking, had joined Apple and Microsoft as $3 trillion companies. In mid-July, the S&P 500, Nasdaq composite and Japan's Nikkei 225 had risen to all-time highs. Investors believed that the high interest rates put in place by the U.S. Federal Reserve were taming inflation without causing a sharp slowdown in the U.S. economy, the world's largest.\n\nThat confidence has taken a hit the past few days. Investors are listening to warnings that Nvidia and other Big Tech stocks have gotten too expensive, and that massive spending on AI might not turn into profits for a while.\n\nAs the markets plummeted Monday, several online brokerage firms including Charles Schwab, Fidelity and Vanguard appeared to be down for thousands of users.\n\nUser reports appeared to peak around and just before 10 a.m. EDT, data from outage tracker Downdectector shows. Some frustrated customers online said that they were unable to log in or access their account balances.\n\n\"Due to a technical issue, some clients may have difficulty logging in to Schwab platforms,\" Charles Schwab wrote on social media platform X Monday morning. \"Please accept our apologies as our teams work to resolve the issue as quickly as possible.\"\n\nBy mid-day, Schwab confirmed that the issue had been resolved.\n\nA Fidelity spokesperson told The Associated Press via email Monday that the company was aware of some customers experiencing \"intermittent issues\" earlier in the day, but said that this is now resolved.\n\nVanguard did not immediately return a request for comment.\n\nAt its peak, Charles Schwab saw nearly 15,000 outage reports from users around 9:50 a.m. EDT, per Downdetector. Fidelity and Vanguard saw another 3,800 and 2,900, respectively, closer to 10 a.m. EDT. User reports appeared to fall notably for all three platforms about an hour later.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8260250682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "14:16:24", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T14:16:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T14:15:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.afr.com/world/north-america/wall-street-opens-in-turmoil-extending-global-sell-off-20240805-p5jzsh", "title": "Wall Street opens in turmoil, extending global sell-off", "body": "Even gold, which has a reputation for offering safety during tumultuous times, slipped nearly 2 per cent.\n\nThat's in part because traders are wondering if the damage has been so severe that the Federal Reserve will have to cut interest rates in an emergency meeting, before its next scheduled decision on Sept. 18. The yield on the two-year Treasury, which closely tracks expectations for the Fed, fell to 3.74 per cent from 3.88 per cent late Friday and from 5 per cent in April.\n\n\"The Fed could ride in on a white horse to save the day with a big rate cut, but the case for an inter-meeting cut seems flimsy,\" said Brian Jacobsen, chief economist at Annex Wealth Management. \"Those are usually reserved for emergencies, like COVID, and an unemployment rate of 4.3 per cent doesn't really seem like an emergency.\"\n\n\"The Fed could respond by stopping\" the shrinking of its holdings of Treasury and other bonds, which could put less upward pressure on longer-term yields, he said. \"That could at least be a symbolic action that they're not blind to what's going on.\"\n\nOf course, the US economy is still growing, and a recession is far from assured. The Fed has been clear about the tightrope it began walking when it started hiking rates sharply in March 2022: Being too aggressive would choke the economy, but going too soft would give inflation more oxygen and hurt everyone.\n\nAfter leaving the federal funds rate steady last week, before several discouraging economic reports hit, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said officials \"have a lot of room to respond if we were to see weakness\" in the job market after raising their main rate to the highest level in more than two decades.\n\nGoldman Sachs economist David Mericle sees a higher chance of a recession following Friday's jobs report. But he still sees only a 25 per cent chance of that, up from 10 per cent, in part \"because the data look fine overall\" and he does not \"see major financial imbalances.\"\n\nStill, stocks of companies whose profits are most closely tied to the economy's strength took heavy losses on the fears about a sharp slowdown. The small companies in the Russell 2000 index dropped 5.5 per cent, further dousing what had been a revival for it and other beaten-down areas of the market.\n\nMaking things worse for Wall Street, Big Tech stocks also tumbled sharply as the market's most popular trade for much of this year continued to unravel. Apple, Nvidia and a handful of other Big Tech stocks known as the \"Magnificent Seven\" had propelled the S&P 500 to dozens of all-time highs this year, in part on a frenzy around artificial-intelligence technology. They were so strong that they overshadowed weakness for areas of the stock market weighed down by high interest rates.\n\nBut Big Tech's momentum turned last month on worries investors had taken their prices too high and expectations for future growth are becoming too difficult to meet. A set of underwhelming profit reports from Tesla and Alphabet added to the pessimism and accelerated the declines.\n\nApple fell 6.8 per cent Monday after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it had slashed its ownership stake in the iPhone maker.\n\nNvidia, the chip company that's become the poster child of Wall Street's AI bonanza, fell even more, 11 per cent. Analysts cut their profit forecasts over the weekend for the company after a report from The Information said Nvidia's new AI chip is delayed. {"uri": "8256493745", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-02", "time": "19:34:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-02T19:34:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-02T19:28:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2810388/", "title": "Money Blog: Co-ops make big changes to food choices | UK News - ExBulletin", "body": "There has been a very serious summer sell-off in stock markets around the world over the past 48 hours, and nervous investors have another reason to continue selling today.\n\nThe U.S. nonfarm payrolls figure, which essentially measures how many jobs were added to the U.S. economy last month, was perhaps one of the most closely watched economic data figures in financial markets, coming in at a much lower-than-expected level in July.\n\nThe U.S. economy added about 114,000 jobs this month, significantly less than the 175,000 jobs that Wall Street had expected. That's the weakest reading since December and the second-weakest since March 2020, when the pandemic was just beginning in the West.\n\nThe June figure was also revised down to 179,000 from the previously healthy figure of 206,000.\n\nWhen factoring in the number of people entering the labor force, the U.S. unemployment rate rose to 4.3% in July, worse than the 4.1% Wall Street had expected.\n\nAnd they have deepened fears that the world's largest economy is heading into recession.\n\nSuch fears began to spread on Wednesday evening when the Federal Reserve decided not to cut interest rates from the 5.25% to 5.5% range it has maintained since July, and some figures the next day suggested U.S. manufacturing activity would decline in July.\n\nThis has already sent U.S. stocks tumbling even before the jobs data was released. All major U.S. stock indexes fell on Thursday, with the most important index, the S&P 500, down 2.5%, the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 1.9%, the tech-heavy Nasdaq down 3.3%, and the Russell 2000, a major index of smaller U.S. companies, down 3%.\n\nThe declines were compounded this afternoon as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq showed signs of a third straight week of losses. The indexes, which had been dragged down by mixed trading updates from big tech companies, have now reached levels last seen in May and are officially in \"correction\" territory.\n\nThat is, it is down more than 10% from its most recent high in July.\n\nSome individual stocks fell even more sharply, with Snapchat parent Snap at one point down 30% and chipmaker Intel down 28%. Shares in Nasdaq-listed British chip designer Arm Holdings fell another 6%, losing a quarter of its market value this week. Amazon, one of the tech giants whose trading updates left Wall Street in shock overnight, fell 12%.\n\nOther asset classes are also falling. Oil prices, which are expected to fall in the event of a U.S. recession, are expected to fall for the fourth straight week, with Brent crude hitting $77.70 a barrel this afternoon, the lowest level since the first week of June.\n\nOn the positive side, gold, a traditional safe haven for investors, is close to its all-time high of $2,483.60 set on July 17 this afternoon.\n\nAnd US Treasury bonds (US government IOUs) have also surged. The yield on the 2-year Treasury note, which closely tracks interest rates (and falls as prices rise), fell below 4% for the first time since May, while the yield on the 10-year Treasury fell to 3.79% at one point, the last time it was at a level since December.\n\nMarket commentators and economists now expect the Fed to cut rates next month.\n\n\"Oh my goodness, did the Fed make a policy mistake? The weakness in the labor market is now more apparent, with job gains falling below the 150,000 threshold considered consistent with a strong economy,\" said Seema Shah, chief global strategist at fund manager Principal Asset Management.\n\n\"With a September rate cut set to happen, the Fed will be hoping it's not too late to act this time around.\"\n\nMichael Brown, market analyst at trading platform Pepperstone, said: \"The July U.S. jobs report showed that labor market conditions continue to cool. There is little in the report that will convince the Federal Reserve to meet its first open market committee of the cycle. [interest rate] \"As hinted at in this week's statement, there will be cuts at the next meeting in September.\"\n\nMeanwhile, European stocks were already down on Thursday and continued to fall today. The FTSE-100 is down 2.15% since Wednesday evening, slightly behind some of its continental peers with greater exposure to technology stocks. Paris' CAC-40 is down 3.1% over the past two sessions, while Germany's DAX is down 4.1%. Italy's MIB is down 5.3% over the same period, while the Netherlands' AEX, an index led by ASML, the world's largest maker of equipment used to make chips, is down 3.9%.\n\nMeanwhile, in the Asia Pacific region, Japanese stocks saw very aggressive selling.\n\nThat's largely due to the yen's surge against the greenback after the Bank of Japan's surprise rate hike on Wednesday. The yen's weakness, which hit a 38-year low against the dollar in June, has been a key driver of Japanese stocks this year, and the currency's surge has upended the market. The Nikkei 225 index, which includes Japan's major blue-chip companies, was already down on Thursday and today fell 5.8%, its biggest one-day drop since March 2020. The Nikkei, which hit a record high earlier this year, is now down 12% since July 12.\n\nMeanwhile, the Topix, a broad index of Japanese stocks, fell 6.2%, its biggest daily decline since 2016.\n\nWhat's interesting about this selloff is that in recent years, when central banks like the Federal Reserve and the Bank of England kept their policy rates at ultra-low levels, bad news about the economy was seen as good news for the market, as it suggested that central banks would keep rates low for longer.\n\nBut everything changed in December 2021 when the Bank of Korea became the first major central bank in the world to raise interest rates, followed by the Federal Reserve.\n\nNow, with interest rates \"normalizing\" for more than two years, bad news about the economy is again being seen as bad news for the markets.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": {"uri": "8260500340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-05", "time": "17:20:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-05T17:20:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-05T17:16:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2812554/", "title": "Dow Jones falls more than 1,200 points on fears of US economic slowdown - ExBulletin", "body": "U.S. stocks fell for a third straight day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average shedding more than 1,200 points, amid growing fears of an economic slowdown driven by a sharp slowdown in hiring and weakening consumer spending.\n\nThe S&P 500 index lost 129 points, or 2.4%, to 5,217 in early afternoon trading, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite fell 2.9%. Investors are fleeing the big tech names that until recently have propelled the U.S. market higher: Apple lost 4.2% while Meta fell about 2% in early afternoon trading. Chipmaker Nvidia fell 5.6%.\n\nThe Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1,238 points in early trading, but pared some of those losses by early afternoon, when it was down 800 points, or 2%, as of 12:05 p.m. ET.\n\nMarkets recovered some of their early losses as Wall Street digested data from the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) services index on Monday, which showed that employment in services picked up in July.\n\n\"The details of the ISM report are encouraging, with economic activity, new orders and employment all rebounding sharply in July,\" Oxford Economics said in a research note Monday. The report \"is consistent with our view of an economy in transition rather than on the brink of collapse.\"\n\nWhat's Driving Stocks Down?\n\nStocks began to lose ground Thursday after weak manufacturing and construction reports fueled fears that the U.S. economy may finally buckle under pressure from high interest rates.\n\nOn Friday, government data showed that hiring last month was much weaker than expected, reinforcing Wall Street fears that a \"soft landing\" in which the U.S. economy might avoid a recession despite 23-year high interest rates could instead turn into a hard landing.\n\n\"The main driver of resistance is the slowing economy,\" Paul Christopher, Wells Fargo's head of global investment strategy, wrote in a report. \"Investors have watched household financial stress worsen over the past two years, but during that time, job growth has remained above its December 2009-December 2019 average of 180,000 new jobs per month.\"\n\nBut Friday's jobs report showed employers added just 114,000 new jobs last month, far fewer than the 175,000 jobs economists had expected, he noted.\n\nTechnology stocks have been hit particularly hard in recent weeks as investors shun artificial intelligence companies amid questions about when the emerging sector will generate profits.\n\n\"It's been a tough few weeks for the AI group as financial results have been released,\" wrote analysts at Melius Research. \"Microsoft, Meta, Google and Amazon have all been asked about the benefits of AI investments. While it's pretty clear that they all need to keep spending, the market remains skeptical about their pace.\"\n\nFinancial Advisor Discusses Stock Market Drop as Unemployment Rate Rises 07:48\n\nThe market rout spread to Asian and European markets, with Japan's benchmark stock index plunging 12.4% on Monday. The Nikkei fell 5.8% on Friday, its worst two-day decline in history.\n\nStocks in Korea and Taiwan also fell sharply, with all three Asian markets hit by investors pulling back from AI-focused companies amid concerns the sector is overhyped.\n\nEuropean markets also opened lower on Monday, with Germany's DAX down 2.3% at 17,267.00 points. The CAC 40 in Paris lost 1.9% to 7,114.33 points and the FTSE 100 in London fell 2.1% to 8,004.19 points.\n\nDespite Monday's rout, U.S. stocks remain in positive territory for the year. The S&P 500, for example, is up 9% year-to-date, even after accounting for the stock market's three-day slide, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average is still up 3%.\n\nWhen will the Fed cut rates?\n\nFaced with the disappointing economic data, Wall Street is concerned that the Federal Reserve has kept its benchmark interest rate too high for too long, raising the risk of a recession. The central bank kept the federal funds rate unchanged at its July 31 meeting to discuss the state of the economy and whether and when it should start cutting rates.\n\nLower interest rates would make it cheaper for U.S. households and businesses to borrow, but it may take time for the effects to be felt across the economy. On Monday, some investors called on the Fed to start cutting rates sooner rather than later to avoid an economic slowdown.\n\nHow likely is the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates in September? 04:14\n\n\"The Federal Reserve must begin easing monetary policy more aggressively than previously anticipated to avoid an imminent recession in the world's largest economy,\" Nigel Green, CEO of deVere Group, an independent financial advisory and asset management firm, said in an email. \"The Fed was late at the start of the cycle, it can't afford to be late again.\"\n\nEconomists still don't expect a recession\n\nAlthough concerns about the weakness of the U.S. economy and market volatility have spread around the world, domestic economic activity remains strong, with many analysts saying a recession remains unlikely. Stephen Brown, deputy chief North America economist at Capital Economics, still expects a soft landing, while acknowledging that the risk of a deeper recession is increasing.\n\nThe economy has been picking up steam this year, with the country's gross domestic product surging to 2.8% in the second quarter, beating expectations. A recession is typically marked by two consecutive quarters of negative GDP. And while the July jobs report was disappointing, analysts point out that it only reflects one month of data, while noting that July's depressed hiring numbers may also have been affected by Hurricane Beryl.\n\n\"It can be wrong to draw too broad conclusions from a single data release,\" Solita Marcelli, chief investment officer for the Americas at UBS Global Wealth Management, told investors in a research note. \"The number of people who reported being unable to work [in July] \"Due to the weather conditions, the number of displaced people rose to 436,000, compared to an average of 33,000 for the month of July since 2000.\"\n\nAimee Picchi is an associate editor at CBS MoneyWatch, where she covers business and personal finance. She previously worked at Bloomberg News and has written for national media outlets including USA Today and Consumer Reports.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online", Apple was holding steadier, up 2%, after reporting better profit and revenue than expected.\n\nWorries are rising the Fed may have kept its main interest rate at a two-decade high for too long. Traders are now betting on a nearly three-in-four chance that the Fed will cut its main interest rate by half a percentage point in September, according to data from CME Group. So, in other words, we went from, you know, months and months of 'When's the Fed going to ease and how much are they going to ease' this year and next to one where growth is plunging and the Fed is behind the curve. So, we've had a change in attitude. It's been based on, you know, some weakening data. [FLASH] So in our opinion, is the economy slowing? Yes. Is there any need for an emergency Fed cut? It doesn't look like it in our opinion.\"\n\nThe market pain eased a bit as the day progressed and stocks pared losses after data showed U.S. services sector activity in July rebounded from a four-year low amid a rise in orders and employment.\n\nBut jitters pervaded, particularly among banks stocks and Big Tech.\n\nOnline brokerages including Charles Schwab and Vanguard reported service disruptions, frustrating investors looking to trade on a day when many sought to dump anything risky.\n\nBitcoin fell more than 15% on Monday amid the frenzied selling, and U.S.-listed shares of crypto-linked companies slumped.\n\nOil also fell on Monday despite worries that a spreading conflict in the Middle East could further hit crude supplies.\n\nAnalysts at Goldman Sachs now see a 25% likelihood of a U.S. recession.
